abstract.text: Add multitasking capability to your video-call apps by using Picture in Picture (PiP).

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Adopting Picture in Picture for video calls

inlineContent.text: Use PiP in your video-call apps so users can multitask with other apps while on video calls. When a user enables PiP, your app scales down to a corner of the screen, so they can see the Home Screen and interact with other apps. In iOS 15 and later,
provides PiP support for video-calling apps, which enables you to deliver a familiar video-calling experience that behaves like FaceTime.
In iOS 16 and later, you can use the camera in Picture in Picture mode by enabling a capture session’s
property. Apps that have a deployment target earlier than iOS 16 require the
entitlement to use the camera in PiP mode.
Providing PiP support begins by choosing a source view to display inside the video-call view controller. You need to add a
to
, so use
or
depending on your need. In iOS 18 and later, you may also use
as your source view. Video-calling apps need to display the remote view, so use
to do so.
To display your source view, create a
and add your source as a subview.
Use
to determine whether the current device supports PiP playback. If PiP isn’t supported on the current device, attempting to initialize a PiP controller returns

content.text: Create a PiP controller using a content source

inlineContent.text: Before you create an
, you need to create an
that represents the source of the content the system displays. A content source requires a video-call view controller, and a source view that contains the content you associate with the video call.
Avoid unintentionally starting PiP by setting the content source on your PiP controller to
or by releasing your PiP controller, when the active call ends.
After creating a content source, use it to initialize
. By default, PiP starts when a user moves to the background if your source view is full-screen, or you set
to
. If your app is in the foreground, you can start PiP by calling
The system uses the source view to determine the source frame for the PiP animation, and the restore target for either when the user returns to the app or PiP stops.
The PiP window doesn’t receive touch events when you use
, so you can’t customize the window’s user interface by adding buttons.
When you use PiP, you respond to life-cycle events by observing
. This allows you to handle your app’s user interface based on the PiP state, along with observing for potential errors.
The system interrupts your capture session when the system or user stashes PiP, so observe
for
to handle the interruption.

When your app is in PiP mode, it can’t assume control of the camera. For example, Camera.app assumes control of the camera when it’s opened, and the system returns camera control when Camera.app finishes with it. You observe
for
to handle the interruption.

abstract.text: Create user interfaces for media playback, complete with transport controls, chapter navigation, picture-in-picture support, and display of subtitles and closed captions.
A controller that responds to user-initiated Picture in Picture playback of video in a floating, resizable window.
An object that represents the source of the content to present in Picture in Picture.
A Boolean value that indicates whether Picture in Picture starts automatically when the controller embeds its content inline and the app transitions to the background.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the current device supports Picture in Picture.
Starts Picture in Picture, if possible.
A protocol to adopt to respond to Picture in Picture events.
A view controller that presents content from a video call in Picture in Picture.
Operate the camera in Split View, Slide Over, Picture in Picture, and Stage Manager modes.

doc://com.apple.avkit/documentation/AVKi.title: Accessing the camera while multitasking on iPad

abstract.text: Add controls to your custom player user interface to invoke Picture in Picture (PiP) playback.

doc://com.apple.avkit/documentation/AVKi.title: Adopting Picture in Picture in a Custom Player

abstract.text: Add Picture in Picture (PiP) playback to your app using a player view controller.

doc://com.apple.avkit/documentation/AVKi.title: Adopting Picture in Picture in a Standard Player

abstract.text: Add advanced multitasking capabilities to your video apps by using Picture in Picture playback in tvOS.

doc://com.apple.avkit/documentation/AVKi.title: Adopting Picture in Picture Playback in tvOS

abstract.text: An interruption caused by the video device temporarily being made unavailable (for example, when used by another capture session).
An interruption caused by the app being sent to the background while using a camera.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the capture session enables access to the camera while multitasking.
A notification the system posts when it interrupts a capture session.
A Core Animation layer that displays video from a camera device.
An object that displays compressed or uncompressed video frames.
A Boolean value that indicates whether an app may continue using the camera at the same time as another foreground app.
A specialized view that creates, configures, and displays Metal objects.
